This is the Religion overview!

This overview contains three sections. The first is dedicated to your Religion. You can check your religious status, chosen Beliefs and even automate [ICON_PEACE] Faith purchases if you want to. The second section will give you an overview of the other World Religions and the third will show you which Beliefs are already taken and by whom.
This is the Espionage Overview!

The Espionage Screen gives you a full overview of your Intelligence network. You can use it to check on the current status of your spies. But this is also [COLOR_ADVISOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]the command center from where you give orders to your spies[/COLOR]: be it to move to a different city, to establish surveillance or to steal a technology.
Choose a Pantheon!

Your people rejoice! You have accumulated enough [ICON_PEACE] Faith [COLOR_ADVISOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]to found a Pantheon[/COLOR], the first step towards founding a Religion.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]After clicking on the Notification below, you will see a selection of Pantheon Beliefs that are available to you. They are generally terrain-based, so choose something you think will help you based on your surroundings.
You can found a Religion!

The sermons of your Great Prophet have been heard and you can now [COLOR_ADVISOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]found a Religion[/COLOR]. Choose a symbol along with its name. After that you will get to choose two additional Beliefs for your new Religion: A Founder Belief (player-level bonuses for the player that founds the Religion) and a Follower Belief (city-level Belief that applies to any city where your Religion spreads).
You can steal a tech!

Your spy is reporting that they have gathered enough intelligence to [COLOR_ADVISOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]steal a technology[/COLOR]. They are waiting for your decision on which technology you want them to steal.
Great Prophet Spawned!

Great Prophets can be used to found a Religion (if you have already founded a Pantheon), to enhance an existing Religion, to spread the religion to other cities or to build a tile improvement that generates [ICON_PEACE] Faith.
You have a spy!

Using the Espionage screen (found in the Additional Information button on the upper right of the screen) you can set your spies up either offensively (to spy and steal in foreign territory) or defensively (to protect your cities and technologies).

You have earned your first [ICON_PEACE] Faith point.[ICON_PEACE] Faith can be used to found a Pantheon, to spawn Great Prophets, and once you have founded a religion to buy Missionaries, Inquisitors and Religious Buildings. Mouse over the [ICON_PEACE] Faith icon in the top menu bar to see how much more [ICON_PEACE] Faith you need for the next threshold.
You have Faith!

Spies can be used either offensively or defensively. To give your spy instructions, open the Espionage screen, which can be found under the Additional Information button on the upper right of the screen.
You have a Spy!

The unwavering Faith of your people has inspired a Great Prophet to emerge![NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Since this is your first Great Prophet I strongly recommend you use him to [COLOR_ADVISOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Found a Religion[/COLOR]. This way you have full control over the Beliefs that the Religion will give you. There are a limited amount of Religions allowed in each game, so claim yours as quickly as you can.
A Great Prophet was born!

All newly-trained non-air Units in this City receive the [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Drill I[ENDCOLOR] Promotion, improving [ICON_STRENGTH] combat strength when fighting in [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]ROUGH[ENDCOLOR] Terrain. Provides a free Castle in the city in which it is built. Boosts city [ICON_CULTURE] Culture output by 20%.
Provides a free Broadcast Tower in all cities. +1 [ICON_CITIZEN] Population in each city and +1 [ICON_HAPPINESS_1] Happiness per city.

2 free Great Scientists appear near the City where the Wonder was built. Provides a free Spaceship Factory in the city in which it is built. +25% [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production when building Spaceship Parts.
+25% generation of [ICON_GREAT_PEOPLE] Great People in all Cities. A free Great Person of your choice appears near the [ICON_CAPITAL] Capital.
+3 [ICON_GOLD] Gold, +2 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture, and +1 [ICON_HAPPINESS_1] Happiness from every Castle.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]City must be built within 2 tiles of a Mountain that is inside your territory.
A free Great Prophet appears. Provides a free Temple in the city in which it is built.

99.9% reduction in effectiveness of enemy spies in the city in which it is built. All other cities in the civilization get a 25% reduction in enemy spy effectiveness. Negates the [ICON_TOURISM] Tourism bonus from other players' Internet technology.

An important defensive National Wonder for a technology-driven civilization. The National Intelligence Agency provides an additional spy, levels up all your existing spies, and provides a 15% reduction in enemy spy effectiveness. A civilization must have a Police Station in all cities before it can construct the National Intelligence Agency.
Provides an additional spy and levels up all your existing spies. Also provides a 15% reduction in enemy spy effectiveness. Must have a Police Station in all cities.

An important building for a civilization trying to spread their religion world-wide from an empire with few, populous cities. Must be built in a Holy City. Doubles religious pressure emanating from this city. A civilization must have a Temple in all cities before it can construct the Grand Temple.
Doubles religious pressure emanating from this City.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Must be built in a Holy City. Must have built a Temple in all Cities. The cost goes up the more cities there are in the empire.
The Shrine is the earliest building that increases the [ICON_PEACE] Faith generated by a city, allowing you to found and spread religions.
Each Recycling Center provides 2 [ICON_RES_ALUMINUM] Aluminum. Maximum of 5 of these buildings in your empire.
Provides 2 [ICON_RES_ALUMINUM] Aluminum. Maximum of 5 of these buildings in your empire.
Bomb Shelters reduce population loss from a nuclear attack on this city by 75%. Duck and Cover!
Reduces population loss from nuclear attack by 75%.
Constabularies slow down the rate at which enemy spies can steal technologies from your city.
Reduces enemy spy stealing rate by 25%.
Police stations slow down the rate at which enemy spies can steal technologies from your city. The city must possess an Constabulary in order to construct the Police Station.
Reduces enemy spy stealing rate by 25%.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]City must have a Constabulary.
Each source of [ICON_RES_INCENSE] Incense and [ICON_RES_WINE] Wine worked by this City produce +1 [ICON_PEACE] Faith and +1 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture.

Monasteries increase a city's [ICON_PEACE] Faith and [ICON_CULTURE] Culture output, especially if the city is near to improved Incense and/or Wine resources. Can only be built in cities following a religion with the Monasteries belief. Construct this building by purchasing it with [ICON_PEACE] Faith.

The Temple increases the [ICON_PEACE] Faith of a city, speeding up the rate at which you can found and spread religions. The city must contain a Shrine (or a Pyramid) before the Temple can be constructed.
Walls increase a city's Defense Strength by 5 and Hit Points by 50, making the city more difficult to capture. Walls are quite useful for cities located along a civilization's frontier.
The Military Base is a mid-game building which increases the city's Defensive Strength by 12 and Hit Points by 25. The city must possess an Arsenal before a Military Base may be constructed.
The Castle is a Medieval-era building which increases the city's Defensive Strength by 7 and Hit Points by 25. The city must possess Walls before the Castle can be constructed.

The Arsenal is a mid-game military building that increases a city's Defense Strength by 9 and Hit Points by 25, making the city more difficult to capture. The city must possess a Castle before it can construct an Arsenal.

The Walls of Babylon are a Babylonian Unique Building, replacing the standard city Walls. The Walls of Babylon increases a city's Defense Strength by 6 and Hit Points by 100 (both significantly more than standard Walls).

The Stele is an Ancient-era building unique to Ethiopia, replacing the Monument. It increases the [ICON_CULTURE] Culture and [ICON_PEACE] Faith of a city, speeding the growth of the city's territory and the civilization's acquisition of Social Policies and Religions.

The Great Prophet is the only unit who can found or enhance a religion. He can also construct the special Holy Site improvement which, when worked, produces lots of [ICON_PEACE] Faith. Alternatively, the Great Prophet can spread religion 4 times (displacing any previous religions in these cities). The Great Prophet is expended when used in any of these ways.

Can be purchased with [ICON_PEACE] Faith in any city with a majority Religion. Once adjacent to a city they can spread their religion to it (expending the Missionary after the second use). If a Missionary enters another civilization without Open Borders, their Religious Strength is reduced each turn. Once their Religious Strength reaches zero, they are destroyed.
Used to spread a religion to cities. May only be obtained by purchasing with [ICON_PEACE] Faith.

Can be purchased with [ICON_PEACE] Faith in any city with a majority Religion that has been enhanced. They can remove other religions from your cities (expending the Inquisitor) or be placed inside a city to protect it from Missionaries and Prophets trying to spread other religions into that city.
Used to remove other religions from cities. May only be obtained by purchasing with [ICON_PEACE] Faith.

Mehal Sefari are the backbone of the Ethiopian army. They start with promotions that give them bonuses fighting in rough terrain and near their capital. They are slightly cheaper to build than the Rifleman that they replace.
Strong, front-line land Unit that specializes in fighting in rough terrain and defending near the Ethiopian capital. Only the Ethiopians may build it.
Classical ranged infantry Unit.

The Composite Bowman is more powerful than the Archer. As a Ranged unit it can deal significant damage to other units up to two hexes away, but it is vulnerable to melee attack. Put Composite Bowman in your city for defense, and guard them with melee units when on the move.
Ranged infantry Unit of the mid-game that must be adjacent to an enemy to strike.

The Gatling Gun is a mid-game non-siege ranged unit. It is much more powerful than earlier ranged units like the Crossbowman. It has only a one-hex range, but still can deal significant damage to other units without being hurt itself. Put Gatling Guns in your city for defense.
Medieval Era Naval Unit used to wrest control of the seas with its ranged attack.

The Galleass is the first naval unit with a ranged attack generally available to the civilizations in the game. It is much stronger than earlier naval units but a bit slower. It cannot initiate melee combat. The Galleass is useful for clearing enemy ships out of shallow waters. It cannot enter Deep Ocean hexes unless it is from Polynesia.
Basic Infantry Unit of the Modern Era.
Atomic Era Unit especially useful for embarking and invading across the sea.
The Marine is an alternative to Infantry. It costs a bit more than Infantry but possesses promotions that enhance its Sight and attack strength when embarked at sea.
Early Air Unit designed to intercept incoming enemy aircraft.

The Triplane is an early air unit. It can be based in any city you own or aboard an aircraft carrier. It can move from city to city (or carrier) and can perform "missions" within its range of 5 tiles. Use triplanes to attack enemy aircraft and ground units, to scout enemy positions, and to defend against enemy air attacks. See the rules on Aircraft for more information.
Early Air Unit that can bombard enemy Units and Cities from the skies.

The Great War Bomber is an early air unit. It is effective against ground targets, less so against naval targets, and it's quite vulnerable to enemy aircraft. The Great War Bomber can be based on a player-owned city or aboard a carrier. It can move from base to base and perform missions within its range of "6." Use it to attack enemy units and cities. When possible, send in triplanes or fighters first to "use up" the enemy's anti-aircraft defenses for that turn. See the rules on Aircraft for more information.
The first of its kind, this powerful late game unit can move after attacking.
The Landship is a powerful and mobile land unit. It can move after combat, allowing it to blow holes in enemy lines and then move into the now-vacant hexes.
Late-game ranged Unit that must be adjacent to an enemy to strike.
Naval Unit that specializes in attacking coastal cities to earn gold and capturing enemy ships.

Naval Unit that attacks as a melee unit. Starts with the first Coastal Raider promotion allowing it to earn gold from attacking coastal cities. May capture any enemy naval units it defeats as prize ships.
Naval Unit that specializes in attacking coastal cities to earn gold and capturing enemy ships. Only the Dutch can build it.

Naval Unit used to specializes in attacking coastal cities to earn gold and capturing enemy ships. Only the Dutch may build it. Heals outside friendly territory. Starts with the first two Coastal Raider promotions allowing it to earn gold from attacking coastal cities. May capture any enemy naval units it defeats as prize ships.

The Great Admiral has the ability to instantly repair every naval and embarked unit in the same hex, as well as in adjacent hexes. The Great Admiral is consumed when performing this action. The Great Admiral also provides a 15% combat bonus to all player-owned naval units within 2 tiles. The Great Admiral is NOT consumed when he provides this bonus.

The Great General can construct the special Citadel improvement which gives a big defensive bonus to any unit occupying it, damages enemy units moving adjacent, and puts all adjacent tiles into your territory. The Great General is consumed when it builds the Citadel. The Great General provides a 15% combat bonus to all player-owned land units within 2 tiles. The Great General is NOT consumed when he provides this bonus.

Great Engineers can construct the special Manufactory improvement, which, when worked, provides a lot of [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production for a city. The Great Engineer can also hurry production of a unit, building or Wonder in a city. The Great Engineer is expended when used in either of these ways.

The Great Merchant can construct the special Custom House improvement which, when worked, produces loads of [ICON_GOLD] Gold. The Great Merchant can also journey to a city-state and perform a "trade mission" which produces gobs of [ICON_GOLD] Gold and garners many Influence Points with the city-state. The Great Merchant is expended when used in either of these ways.

The Great Scientist can construct the special Academy improvement which, when worked, produces lots of [ICON_RESEARCH] Science. Further, the Great Scientist lets you immediately gain a large amount of science based on the science output of your civilization. The Great Scientist is expended when used in either of these ways.
Great War Infantry is the basic Modern era combat unit. It's significantly stronger than its predecessor, the Rifleman.
Naval Unit specialized in warding off enemy aircraft. Can hold 3 Missiles. Used to hunt down and destroy enemy Submarines.
Invisible to all Units except Destroyers, Missile Cruisers and other Submarines, or until it attacks or is adjacent to another unit. Can carry 2 Missiles, and is specialized in attacking Naval Units.

Invisible to all Units except Destroyers, Missile Cruisers and other Submarines, or until it attacks or is adjacent to another unit. Can cause major damage to other ships if they get into range without being seen.
Isn't benefiting from any defensive terrain bonuses, but is otherwise stronger than any other military unit in the game.
Fast and powerful late-game Unit.
Fast and powerful late game Unit.
Fast and powerful late game Unit.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Only the Germans may build it. This Unit has 1 additional movement compared to the Tank, which it replaces.
Mounted Unit capable of fighting toe-to-toe with contemporary infantry units.

Mounted Unit capable of fighting toe-to-toe with contemporary infantry units. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Only the Russians may build it. This Unit has a combat bonus when fighting enemies that have already taken damage.
Mounted Unit specialized in defeating enemy Mounted Units.
Mounted Unit specialized in defeating enemy Mounted Units. May only be built by the Ottomans. This Unit is faster and can see further than the Lancer, which it replaces.
Powerful Medieval Mounted Unit, weak to Pikemen. Only the Songhai may build it. This Unit is not penalized when attacking Cities, unlike the Knight which it replaces.
A fast Ranged Unit highly effective on flat ground.
A fast Ranged Unit. Only the Egyptians may build it. This Unit does not require [ICON_RES_HORSE] Horses to be built, unlike the Chariot Archer which it replaces.

The Crossbowman is more powerful than the Composite Bowman. As a Ranged unit it can deal significant damage to other Medieval Era units up to two hexes away, but it is vulnerable to melee attack. Put Crossbowmen in your city for defense, and guard them with melee units when on the move.
Most powerful Infantry Unit in the game until Mechanized Infantry.

Infantry is significantly stronger than its predecessor, the Great War Infantry. Modern combat is increasingly complex, and on its own an Infantry unit is vulnerable to air, artillery and tank attack. When possible Infantry should be supported by artillery, tanks, and air (or anti-air) units.

The Trireme is the first naval unit available to civilizations in the game. It is a melee attack unit, engaging units at sea or cities (but it has no ranged attack). The Trireme is useful for clearing barbarian ships out of home waters and for limited exploration (it cannot enter Deep Ocean hexes outside of the city borders unless it is from Polynesia).
Ancient Era Naval Unit used to wrest control of the seas through melee attacks on naval units and cities.

The Galley is a Barbarian unit which remains in coastal hexes, looking for embarked units to destroy. It is far weaker than any other naval units, but can be dangerous in packs. It is a melee attack unit, engaging units at sea or cities (but it has no ranged attack).

The Caravel is a significant upgrade to a civilization's naval power. A Melee unit, it is stronger and faster than a Trireme, and it can enter Deep Ocean hexes. It is quick, giving it a promotion that gives it a good chance to withdraw to the rear before an enemy naval melee attack can occur. The Caravel has an enhanced sight radius, making it the eyes and ears of the mid-game navy. This sight bonus is lost if the Caravel is upgraded to a Destroyer.
Fast Renaissance exploration Unit with an enhanced sight radius that can enter Ocean. Fights as a naval melee unit.

The Destroyer is a naval melee attack unit designed to hunt down and destroy submarines and to provide anti-aircraft support. It often operates as an escort to embarked units, battleships and carriers when in range of enemy planes and subs. It is quick, giving it a promotion that gives it a good chance to withdraw to the rear before an enemy naval melee attack can occur.
Fast late game ship making it highly effective at recon. Also used to hunt down and destroy enemy Submarines. Fights as a naval melee unit.

Ironclads are the first steam-powered warships available. Fighting as a naval melee unit, they are harder to kill than any sailing vessel, and their Combat strength is higher. Use them primarily for in-shore defense and to assault cities.
A very powerful naval melee unit, the Ironclad pays for its strength by being slower in ocean tiles.
Unit specialized in fighting Modern Armor and Tanks. It is capable of hovering over mountains, but takes damage if ending its turn on one.

Spies and Diplomats
{TXT_KEY_CONCEPT_ESPIONAGE_SPIES_TOPIC}

You will earn your first Spy when any civ in the game enters the Renaissance Era. Spies can be assigned to a city in another civilization with the goal of stealing technology and gathering information. You can also assign a Spy to one of your own cities to have a chance to slow down, discover, or kill an enemy spy.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]When assigning a Spy to the capital of another civilization, you can choose to assign them as a Diplomat. Diplomats do not steal technology, and are only there to gather information. Additionally, if the target civilization is following a different Ideology, your Diplomat will start spreading Propoganda, increasing your [ICON_TOURISM] Tourism bonus in that civilization. Because they are a Diplomat, they are in no danger from other spies. They become even more useful when the World Congress is founded, delivering information on how other civilizations are planning to vote, and allowing votes to be traded via diplomacy.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]To deploy your first Spy or Diplomat, select "Espionage Overview" from within the "Additional Information" menu.
What is a Spy or Diplomat?
Moving Spies
{TXT_KEY_CONCEPT_ESPIONAGE_MOVING_SPIES_TOPIC}

To move a spy, open the "Espionage Overview" screen, and click the "Move" button next to a spy you want to relocate. After clicking the "Move" button, click on the destination city name on the right side of the screen (either one of yours or a target civilization). How do I use spies to steal technology?

Your spies can steal technology from a more advanced civilization. To attempt to steal technology, first, move a spy to a target city within another civilization. Once the spy arrives, there will be a period of time where they are "Establishing Surveillance" (noted in the "Activity" column). Once surveillance is established, you will know whether the target has technology that you can steal. If they do, the time it takes to steal the technology depends on how much science the target city is producing, and the rank of your spy. The higher your rank, the more quickly you will be able to steal technology. The higher the science output, the faster your spy can work.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Other factors that can affect the time it takes to steal technology includes defensive buildings like the Police Station or the Great Firewall wonder, which can stop a spy completely. This, of course, will have a negative effect on your diplomatic relations with the target civilization.

Counter-Intelligence
{TXT_KEY_CONCEPT_ESPIONAGE_COUNTER_INTEL_TOPIC}

You can defend against enemy spies by establishing counter-intelligence. To do this, move a spy into one of your cities that you suspect will be a target (usually a city with a high science output). Constabularies and Police
{TXT_KEY_CONCEPT_ESPIONAGE_POLICE_STATION_TOPIC}

You can slow down enemy spies by building Constabularies and Police Stations in your cities. If a city contains a Constabulary or a Police Station, the time it takes to steal technology is increased by 25% for each.
How can I slow the progress of an enemy spy?
National Intelligence Agency
{TXT_KEY_CONCEPT_ESPIONAGE_NATIONAL_INTELLIGENCE_TOPIC}
The National Intelligence Agency National Wonder provides your civilization with an additional spy, and will level-up all your existing spies.
How can I get additional spies?
The Great Firewall
{TXT_KEY_CONCEPT_ESPIONAGE_GREAT_FIREWALL_TOPIC}

The Great Firewall Wonder reduces the effectiveness of enemy spies by 99.9% in the city in which it was built, and 25% in all other cities within your civilization. It also negates the [ICON_TOURISM] Tourism bonus from other players' Internet technology.
How can I slow the progress of an enemy spy?
Detecting a Spy
{TXT_KEY_CONCEPT_ESPIONAGE_GETTING_CAUGHT_TOPIC}

Spies have a small chance of getting caught whenever they steal technology. {TXT_KEY_CONCEPT_ESPIONAGE_MORE_TOPIC}

How do I get more spies?
Spy Experience
{TXT_KEY_CONCEPT_ESPIONAGE_PROMOTIONS_TOPIC}
With each successful mission, your spies will gain experience and "level-up". With each successive level, your spies will perform their missions more quickly and reliably.

{TXT_KEY_CONCEPT_RELIGION_FAITH_EARNING_TOPIC}

[ICON_PEACE] Faith is the currency which enables you to found a Pantheon, makes Great Prophets spawn and can be used to purchase religious units and buildings.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]There are several sources for [ICON_PEACE] Faith points. There are buildings or wonders that award a certain amount of [ICON_PEACE] Faith per round if you build them in your cities. Some Natural Wonders can also generate it when they are being worked. You can find [ICON_PEACE] Faith in Ancient Ruins. If you befriend a religious city-state they will also contribute with regular gifts. And the last source of [ICON_PEACE] Faith is the tile improvement Holy Site that Great Prophets can erect on your lands.
How can I earn Faith?
Pantheons
{TXT_KEY_CONCEPT_RELIGION_PANTHEONS_TOPIC}

Pantheons are the first step towards founding a full Religion. Once you've accumulated a certain amount of [ICON_PEACE] Faith you will be able to select a Pantheon Belief. The Pantheon Belief you choose will be the basis for any later Religion you might found so choose wisely as it may stay with you for the whole game. The amount of [ICON_PEACE] Faith it takes to found a Pantheon will increase with every Pantheon that has been founded on the whole map.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Pantheons are an early approach to Religion. Consequently it is only possible to found a Pantheon throughout the early ages depending on the developments of Religions around you. Once you've chosen your Pantheon Belief, it will immediately be available throughout your entire civilization, and will automatically expand to new cities until you found a full Religion.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Note that players will no longer be able to found a new Pantheon if another player has already Enhanced their Religion, and the number of active Pantheons matches or exceeds the number of Religions allowable in the current game.
What is a Pantheon?
Founding a Religion
{TXT_KEY_CONCEPT_RELIGION_FOUNDING_RELIGION_TOPIC}

Once you have a Great Prophet and have previously founded a Pantheon you can use the Great Prophet to found a full Religion. This is done by selecting the Great Prophet (make sure he is located in a city), and clicking the "Found Religion" icon on the Unit Panel. You will now be presented with options to choose what sort of Religion you would like for your civilization. Select a symbol and name for your Religion, as well as Founder and Follower Beliefs, which determine what benefits will be awarded. You confirm those choices by clicking on the [ICON_RELIGION] Found Religion button in the lower right of the selection screen.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]There is a limit of how many Religions can be founded in any game, and it's based on map size. That limit will always be lower than the default number of Civilizations in that game, so not everyone gets to found their own Religion.
How do I found a Religion?
Spending Faith
{TXT_KEY_CONCEPT_RELIGION_FAITH_SPENDING_TOPIC}

[ICON_PEACE] Faith can be spent in several ways. It can be used to purchase religious units or buildings or it will get expended to spawn a Great Prophet, or, once you enter the Industrial Era, another Great Person.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The [ICON_PEACE] Faith you've accumulated will automatically be spent on spawning a Great Prophet once you've reached a certain threshold (to see this hover your mouse over the [ICON_PEACE] icon in the Status Bar). Once you enter the Industrial Era, you can spend Faith on other Great People as well, depending on which Social Policy branches you've unlocked.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]You can also choose to spend your accumulated [ICON_PEACE] Faith on Units or buildings. This can be done in the Purchase menu of the City Screen. Missionaries and Inquisitors are available in every city that follows a Religion while the respective buildings are only available if the Majority Religion contains a Belief that unlocks the purchase of a Religious Building.
What can I do with Faith?
Beliefs
{TXT_KEY_CONCEPT_RELIGION_BELIEFS_TOPIC}

When you found a Pantheon or when you later in the game found or enhance a Religion there are a number of different slots you can fill with a selection of Beliefs. The types of Beliefs you get to select are Pantheon Beliefs, Founder Beliefs, Follower Beliefs and Enhancer Beliefs. There are Civilizations that, due to their unique trait, get to choose an additional Bonus Belief.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Beliefs are picked on a first come first serve basis. When any Belief has been picked it will not be available for any other Civilization which is founding or enhancing their Religion afterwards. This makes being the first to get to this point very valuable.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]A full list of all the different Beliefs can be found in the Religion section of the Civilopedia.
What are Beliefs?
Pantheon Beliefs
{TXT_KEY_CONCEPT_RELIGION_PANTHEON_BELIEFS_TOPIC}

This is a special type of follower benefit that is especially useful early in the game (usually for improving yields). They kick in for any city where this Pantheon or Religion is practiced by a majority of the citizens. These Beliefs will make their way into main Religions later in the game as some of the Civilizations choose to go beyond a mere Pantheon and found a Religion.
What are Pantheon Beliefs?
Follower Beliefs
{TXT_KEY_CONCEPT_RELIGION_FOLLOWER_TOPIC}
These attributes are active at the city level. They kick in for any city where this Religion is practiced by a majority of the citizens.
What are Follower Beliefs?
Founder Beliefs
{TXT_KEY_CONCEPT_RELIGION_FOUNDER_TOPIC}

These are player-level bonuses. These positive game effects are received by the player that founded a Religion as long as he still controls the Holy City where the Religion originated. Most of these are directly tied to the spread of the Religion across the map, giving the founder of a Religion a strong incentive to spread his Religion far and wide.
What are Founder Beliefs?
Enhancer Beliefs
{TXT_KEY_CONCEPT_RELIGION_ENHANCER_TOPIC}
These benefits improve the religious spread. Depending on the individual Belief chosen this can be through more powerful religious units or through stronger natural spread.
What are Enhancer Beliefs?
Spreading Religion
{TXT_KEY_CONCEPT_RELIGION_SPREADING_RELIGION_TOPIC}

There are two ways that Religion spreads: The natural spread that the holy city as well as any other religious city generates and the deliberate actions a player can perform to convert other cities.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The natural spread of Religion is fairly straight-forward. Any city that has a majority Religion (more than half of their citizens are following a single Religion) exerts pressure up to 10 hexes from the city. If another city is within that range, and they do not yet have a majority religion, then the pressure will slowly start to convert citizens. If the city already has a majority religion, then it will take two or more cities exerting pressure to start converting citizens. The more cities exerting pressure on the target city, the faster a city's citizens will be converted. You can view your own outward religious pressure, as well as incoming pressure by mousing over the Religion icon on the city banner (if it already has a Pantheon or Religion).[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]To speed up the spread of your Religion the following options are available to you: You can purchase Missionaries by spending [ICON_PEACE] Faith in any city that already has the Religion you wish to spread as its majority. The Missionary will be grayed out if you don't have enough [ICON_PEACE] Faith to acquire it. Once you have a Missionary you can move him into or next to the city you wish to convert and click on the Spread Religion button in his action menu which will normally expend him after two uses.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Great Prophets can spread Religion in a similar fashion but additionally they abolish any other Religions that might be present in their target city. They can perform this action multiple times before being expended.
How does Religion spread?

{TXT_KEY_CONCEPT_RELIGION_ENHANCING_RELIGION_TOPIC}

Religious Units
{TXT_KEY_CONCEPT_RELIGION_UNITS_TOPIC}

There are 3 units that have an impact on Religion: Great Prophets, Missionaries and Inquisitors. While Great Prophets and Missionaries are useful to enhance and spread Religions, Inquisitors defend against unwanted other Religions.
Do units play a role in Religion?
Majority Religion
{TXT_KEY_CONCEPT_RELIGION_MAJORITY_TOPIC}

Each citizen in a city is either an atheist or follows a Religion. Natural and deliberate spread of a Religion to a city converts them, and once one Religion has a majority of citizens as followers, this city will be considered to follow said religion. At that point, religious units and buildings of that religion can be bought in the city screen.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]If the majority of citizens follows one Religion, the symbol of that Religion will be displayed in the city banner.
How does a Religion become the Majority Religion?
Defending Against a Religion
{TXT_KEY_CONCEPT_RELIGION_DEFENDING_TOPIC}

To defend against enemy Missionaries or Great Prophets trying to convert your cities, buy an Inquisitor. These units can be stationed in a city to protect it from conversion. How do I defend against a Religion?

You may choose to intimidate a city-state with the goal of asking for tribute. Tribute can be in the form of a worker, or a lump-sum of gold. The world is composed of a mixture of large and small islands.
There are five different "flavors" of city-states. Each can provide you with different benefits if you befriend or ally with them.
A unit's health is measured in "Hit Points". When fully healthy, all combat units have 100 hit points. As it takes damage, it loses hit points. If a unit's hit points reach 0, it is destroyed.

A fully healthy unit has 100 "hit points" (HPs). When a unit takes damage during combat it loses HPs, and if it reaches 0 HPs, it is destroyed.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]A unit that has taken damage is weaker than a healthy unit, and it is closer to destruction. Wherever possible, it's a good idea to "rotate out" damaged units from battle to allow them to heal up before reentering the fray. This, of course, is not always possible.
A fully-healthy city has 200 hit points. As it takes damage, the city's hit points are reduced. If a city's hit points reach 0, an enemy unit can capture the city by entering its tile.

To heal damage, a unit must remain inactive for a turn. The amount of damage that a unit heals depends upon the unit's location.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]In a City: A unit heals 25 HPs per turn.[NEWLINE]In Friendly Territory: 20 HP per turn.[NEWLINE]In Neutral or Enemy Territory: 10 HP per turn.[NEWLINE]Note that certain promotions will accelerate a unit's healing rate.
Naval units cannot heal unless in Friendly territory, where they heal 20 HPs per turn.
A Great General provides a 15% combat bonus to all friendly land units within 2 tiles. This combat bonus applies to all forms of land combat: melee, ranged, defense, and so forth.

A Great Scientist can give you a considerable boost towards your next tech, or the unit can be expended to construct an Academy improvement, which provides beakers per turn when the tile is worked. See the section on Great People for more details.

The unit's "range" stat determines the distance at which a unit can launch a ranged attack. A range of "2" means that the target can be in an adjacent tile or one tile distant. A range of "1" would mean that the target had to be adjacent to the attacker.

In general, desert hexes are remarkably unuseful. They provide no benefits to cities (unless the desert contains an oasis or resource, of course, or if it has access to fresh water).[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]City Yield: none[NEWLINE]Movement Cost: 1[NEWLINE]Combat Modifier: 0%

Generally, grassland produces the most food of any terrain types. Cities constructed near to grasslands will tend to grow faster than cities built elsewhere.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]City Yield: 2 food[NEWLINE]Movement Cost: 1[NEWLINE]Combat Modifier: 0%

Plains provide a mix of food and production to a nearby city. A city surrounded by plains will grow more slowly than one in grassland, but it will be far more productive. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE]City Yield: 1 food, 1 production[NEWLINE]Movement Cost: 1[NEWLINE]Combat Modifier: 0%

Snow is quite unproductive, with no food or production benefit to a nearby city. Of course a snow hex might contain a useful resource, but otherwise they're just cold and barren.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]City Yield: none[NEWLINE]Movement Cost: 1[NEWLINE]Combat Modifier: 0%

Tundra is the semi-frozen land found in the world's colder climates. It is less useful than plains or grassland, but slightly better than desert. Nobody builds cities in the tundra unless they're desperate for resources - or they've got nowhere else to go.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]City Yield: 1 food[NEWLINE]Movement Cost: 1[NEWLINE]Combat Modifier: 0%

There are six types of non-combat units: Settlers, Workers, Work Boats, Great People, Spaceship Parts, and Religious Units. Each is critically important to a civilization's success. As the name "non-combat" would suggest, these units cannot fight. If attacked by an enemy unit while alone in a hex they are automatically captured or destroyed. Therefore it usually makes sense to escort them with a military unit when sending them out into the wilderness.

Once you or another civ have discovered Civil Service, you can enter into an Open Borders agreement with any civ where you have established an Embassy. (City-States can't make Open Borders agreements.) While an Open Borders agreement is in effect, the other civ's units can enter your territory without automatically triggering war. If the agreement is mutual, either civ's units can enter the other's territory freely; however it doesn't have to be mutual: one civ can grant another Open Borders without automatically receiving it in return.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]An Open Borders agreement lasts for 20 turns. When 20 turns have passed, the agreement must be renegotiated or it lapses.

Generally, units move from hex to hex, paying the "Movement Cost" required to enter the new hex. Units are subject to "Stacking" limitations - two military units may not end their turn in the same hex, nor can two non-military units, but one military and one non-military unit may end their turn stacked in the same hex. Note that embarked military units, as well as Great Generals and Great Admirals, are all considered non-military, and can be stacked with a military unit for protection.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Most units are limited in where they can move - land units cannot enter mountain hexes and naval units cannot enter land hexes (except for port cities). Improvements like roads and railroads speed a unit's movement through land hexes.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Check out the section on Movement for details.

At the start of the game, your land units cannot enter any water tiles. However, once you've learned the Optics technology, you can earn the promotion that allows land units to "embark" and move into coastal water tiles. To embark a unit, move the unit to a coastal tile and then click on the "Embark" Action. Once embarked, the unit must move into water. (Optics allows movement into coastal water only. The later Astronomy tech allows embarked units to enter ocean tiles.)[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]In the water the embarked unit is very slow and almost helpless. It is able to defend itself to a certain degree, but it cannot attack and should not be left alone for too long on the open ocean. It's critical to accompany embarked land units with a strong naval defense.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]When the unit is adjacent to a land tile, you can click on the "Disembark" action. The unit will then be able to return to dry land. Alternatively you can right-click on a land tile and the unit will disembark automatically.

You've so totally angered a City-State that it's grown wary of you. This occurs if you've declared war on too many of the City-States around you - word will spread, and your minimum influence level with large groups of City-States will permanently drop from 0 to -20 (meaning that your influence can degrade well below 0).
Wary
While at war with a City-State, your influence will remain negative and they certainly won't give you any stuff.

You can declare war on a City-State at any time. You can do so through the Diplomatic Panel or by ordering one of your units to attack a City-State's unit or city. You can offer peace to a City-State through the Diplomatic Panel or by clicking on the city.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]It's important to remember that if you attack too many City-States, many will grow wary of you, causing your minimum influence level to permanently drop from 0 to -20.
Special Ability: Free Science
You can expend your Great Scientist to immediately gain a lump sum of science equal to the average science output of your civilization for the previous eight turns.

With the single exception of the monument, which has no prerequisites and is available to build at the start of the game, you need knowledge of a specific technology to construct a building. For example, you must learn bronze working before you can build a barracks.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Some buildings have resource prerequisites as well - for instance a city must have an improved source of horses or ivory nearby to construct a circus.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Also, some buildings have building prerequisites. You can't build a temple in a city unless you've already constructed a shrine there.

Specialists are citizens who have been assigned to work in a building constructed in their city. There are four kinds of specialists in Civilization V: Scientists, Merchants, Artists, and Engineers. A museum, for example, allows one or two citizens to be assigned to work in the building as Artist specialists. Not all buildings allow specialists to be assigned to them. See the individual building entries for details.

Great People can move about the board like any other units. They are non-combat units, which means that they cannot stack in a tile with other non-combat units (Workers, Settlers), but they can stack with one military unit. If an enemy unit enters a Great Person's tile, that Great Person is automatically destroyed (the enemy doesn't get it.) The exception to this rule is the Great Prophet, which can be captured.

A city's owner may station a military unit inside the city to bolster its defenses. A portion of the garrisoned unit's combat strength is added to the city's strength. The garrisoned unit will take no damage when the city is attacked; however, if the city is captured the garrisoned unit is destroyed.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]A unit stationed in the city may attack surrounding enemy units while the city will still receive its garrison bonus.
Withdraw Before Melee
Unit will withdraw when faced with melee attack. Chance of withdrawal decreased against fast enemy units or if there are limited open tiles behind the unit.
